00001 /**********************************************
00002 
00003 Author: Julie Betlach
00004 
00005 Adapted from code written by: Terry Caton, tcaton(a)hotmail.com
00006 Project Webpage: http://cajun-jsonapi.sourceforge.net/
00007 
00008 Original code parsed files in json format.
00009 Code now parses files in PDI format for a project for Washington University, 
00010 course CSE 533S: Pattern Oriented Software Design and Development, Summer 2009.
00011 
00012 File Name: Elements.h
00013 
00014 File Description: The Elements.h file is a part of the PDI parser.  It provides the implementation
00015 of the different element types: ARRAY_ELEMENT, DISPLAY_ELEMENT, and NULL_ELEMENT.
00016 ***********************************************/
00017 
00018 #pragma once
00019 
00020 #include <vector>
00021 #include <list>
00022 #include <string>

00024 
00025 namespace PDI
00026 {
00027 
00028 class Visitor;
00029 class ConstVisitor;
00030 
00031 enum ElementType
00032 {
00033    ARRAY_ELEMENT,
00034    DISPLAY_ELEMENT,
00035    NULL_ELEMENT
00036 };
00037 
00038 
00040 // base class - provides little useful in client code except constructor
00041 
00042 /**********************
00043 Class Name: Element
00044 Class Description: This class is the base class for the element type classes.
00045 The Element class and ElementImp class follow the Pimple Design Pattern.
00046 The majority of this class existed in the CAJUN JSON parser.  However, it has been
00047 modified to suit our needs as explained below.
00048 
00049 Each DisplayElement has three components: Name, Type, Size.
00050 The interface for the SetName function (used to place the name into the member variable) 
00051 and the Name function (used to obtain the value of the member variable) have been defined here.
00052 The actual member variable that holds the Name is not in the Element class.  It is in the
00053 ElementImp_T class.  This was done because the Element class did not need to know about the
00054 member variable.
00055 ***********************/
00056 class ElementImp;
00057 class Element
00058 {
00059 public:
00060    // note: nothing virtual in here! and only one (1) pointer member
00061    Element();
00062    Element(const Element& element);
00063    ~Element();
00064 
00065    Element& operator= (const Element& element);
00066    
00067    ElementType Type() const;
00068 
00069    // const & non-const visitor interfaces
00070    void Accept(Visitor& visitor);
00071    void Accept(ConstVisitor& visitor) const;
00072 
00073    void SetName(const std::string& nameIn);
00074    const std::string& Name() const;
00075 
00076 protected:
00077    Element(ElementImp* elementImp);
00078 
00079    ElementImp& ImpBase();
00080    const ElementImp& ImpBase() const;
00081 
00082 private:
00083    ElementImp* m_pElementImp;
00084 };
00085 
00086 
00088 // template base class for all "concrete" element types. employs "curiously 
00089 // recursive template pattern", also provides little interface used in client 
00090 // code 
00091 
00092 /**********************
00093 Class Name: Element_T
00094 Class Description: This class is a template class for the element type classes.
00095 This class existed in the CAJUN JSON parser and has not changed.
00096 ***********************/
00097 template <typename ElementImpTypeT>
00098 class Element_T : public Element
00099 {
00100 public:
00101    static ElementType Type_i();
00102 
00103 protected:
00104    Element_T();
00105 
00106    //  return type is covariant with ImpBase(), but compiler doesn't know it (can't forward-declare inheritance)
00107    ElementImpTypeT& Imp() { return static_cast<ElementImpTypeT&>(ImpBase()); }
00108    const ElementImpTypeT& Imp() const { return static_cast<const ElementImpTypeT&>(ImpBase()); }
00109 };
00110 
00111 
00112 
00114 // Array - mimics std::list<Element>, the array contents are 
00115 // effectively heterogeneous thanks to the Element base class
00116 /**********************
00117 Class Name: Array
00118 Class Description: The Array class defines the interface to the ArrayImp class.
00119 The Array class and ArrayImp class follow the Pimple Design Pattern.
00120 The majority of this class existed in the CAJUN JSON parser as the OBJECT_ELEMENT.  However, it has been
00121 modified to suit our needs as explained below.
00122 
00123 The list is now a list of elements.  Previously, it was a list of member structs which contained both a
00124 name and an element.  The concept of the struct was removed because the name field was moved into the element.
00125 This Array class does not really hold items in the normal Array sense (in that you have item[0], item[1], etc.)
00126 Instead it contains an ordered list of elements.
00127 
00128 The concept of dimension was added to this class.  Our PDI format allows the user to specify a number after the
00129 closing bracket which specifies the dimension of the array.  Rather than storing extra elements in the array,
00130 it was more efficient just to store the dimension read in from the file.  When an InstructionSet is created
00131 from the Array element, the dimension will be passed into its constructor and it will appropriately handle 
00132 dealing with the buffer of bits being sniffed by Wireshark.
00133 ***********************/
00134 class ArrayImp;
00135 class Array : public Element_T<ArrayImp>
00136 {
00137 public:
00138    typedef std::list<Element> Members; // map faster, but does not preserve order
00139    typedef Members::iterator iterator;
00140    typedef Members::const_iterator const_iterator;
00141 
00142    Array(); // necessary, or we get linker errors... ?
00143 
00144    iterator Begin();
00145    iterator End();
00146    const_iterator Begin() const;
00147    const_iterator End() const;
00148 
00149    size_t Size() const;  // This is the number of elements in the array.
00150    bool Empty() const;
00151 
00152    size_t Dimension() const;  // This is the dimension read in from the file.
00153    void SetDimension(size_t nDimension);
00154 
00155    iterator Find(const std::string& name);
00156    const_iterator Find(const std::string& name) const;
00157 
00158    iterator Insert(const Element& element);
00159    iterator Insert(const Element& element, iterator itWhere);
00160    iterator Erase(iterator itWhere);
00161 
00162    Element& operator [] (const std::string& name);
00163    const Element& operator [] (const std::string& name) const;
00164 
00165    void Clear();
00166 };
00167 
00168 
00169 /**********************
00170 Class Name: DisplayElement
00171 Class Description: The DisplayElement class defines the interface to the DisplayElementImp class.
00172 The DisplayElement class and DisplayElementImp class follow the Pimple Design Pattern.
00173 The majority of this class existed in the CAJUN JSON parser as the OBJECT_STRING.  However, it has been
00174 modified to suit our needs as explained below.
00175 
00176 The class has a very similar interface as before, however, the names of the class and the functions have
00177 been changed to be more clear about the new functionality of the class, to support DisplayElements which
00178 consist of a display type and size.
00179 ***********************/
00180 class DisplayElementImp;
00181 class DisplayElement : public Element_T<DisplayElementImp>
00182 {
00183 public:
00184    DisplayElement(const std::string& s = std::string());
00185    DisplayElement& operator = (const std::string& s);
00186 
00187    operator const std::string&() const;
00188    operator std::string&();
00189 };
00190 
00191 
00192 
00193 /**********************
00194 Class Name: Null
00195 Class Description: The Null class defines the interface to the NullImp class.
00196 The Null class and NullImp class follow the Pimple Design Pattern.
00197 This class existed in the CAJUN JSON parser.  It has not been modified.
00198 
00199 JSON supported Null elements.  However, our PDI language does not.  However, this class was
00200 retained so that it could be used as a default type prior to us knowing the element type.
00201 ***********************/
00202 class NullImp;
00203 class Null : public Element_T<NullImp>
00204 {};
